infodynamics.measures.mixed

Interface MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateWithDiscrete

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateWithDiscreteGaussian, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateWithDiscreteKernel, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateWithDiscreteKraskov, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateWithDiscreteSymbolic

    public interface MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateWithDiscrete

    Interface defining computation of the differential mutual information between a given multivariate set of observations and a discrete variable. This is done by examining the conditional probability distribution (given the discrete variable) against the probability distribution for the multivariate set.

    Usage intended for the child classes:

    1. Construct the child class
    2. initialise(int, int) to tell the class the number of dimensions of the continuous observations, and the base (number of available states) of the discrete variable.
    3. Set properties using setProperty(String, String)
    4. Provide the observations to the calculator using: setObservations(double[][], int[]).
    5. Compute the required information-theoretic results, primarily: computeAverageLocalOfObservations() to return the average MI; or other calls to compute local values or statistical significance.

    These calculators are EXPERIMENTAL -- not properly tested, and not well documented. The intended calling pattern is similar to MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate

    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

    • Method Detail

      • initialise

        void initialise(int dimensions,
              int base)
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Initialise the calculator for use or reuse. This clears any previously supplied observations, but preserves the supplied properties.
        Parameters:
        dimensions - number of joint continuous variables
        base - number of states in the discrete observations
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setProperty

        void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception

        Set the required property of the calculator to the given value. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        There are no general properties settable on all child classes; each child class may define their own properties.

        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of property
        propertyValue - value of property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setObservations

        void setObservations(double[][] continuousObservations,
                   int[] discreteObservations)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Set the properties from which the mutual information should be computed.
        Parameters:
        continuousObservations - observations of the joint continuous variables; first index is time or observation number, second index is variable number (the number of variables should be equal to the number of dimensions set in initialise(int, int).)
        discreteObservations - observations of the discrete variable; must be the same number of observations as supplied for continuousObservations. Each observation must lie in the range 0..base-1, where base was set by initialise(int, int).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        double computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the average mutual information from the previously supplied observations via setObservations(double[][], int[])
        Returns:
        a scalar for the average mutual information
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][] contStates,
                                             int[] discreteStates)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the local mutual information for each pair of continuous and discrete values supplied here, using probability distribution functions generated using the observations previously supplied to the method setObservations(double[][], int[]).
        Parameters:
        contStates - observations of the joint continuous variables, as specified in setObservations(double[][], int[])
        discreteStates - observations of the discrete variable, as specified in setObservations(double[][], int[])
        Returns:
        a time series of the local mutual information values for each supplied observation
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception

        Compute the empiricial statistical significance of the mutual information of the previously supplied observations via setObservations(double[][], int[]). We destroy the p(x,y) correlations, while retaining the p(x), p(y) marginals, to check how significant this mutual information actually was. Specifically, this method returns an EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution object containing numPermutationsToCheck surrogate measurements where the discrete data is shuffled against the continuous data set.

        This is in the spirit of Chavez et. al. which was performed for Transfer entropy.

        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - the number of permuted surrogates to examine
        Returns:
        the proportion of MI scores from the distribution which have higher or equal MIs to ours.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "Chavez et. al., 'Statistical assessment of nonlinear causality: application to epileptic EEG signals', Journal of Neuroscience Methods 124 (2003) 113-128"

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception

        Compute the empiricial statistical significance of the mutual information of the previously supplied observations via setObservations(double[][], int[]). This method performs as per computeSignificance(int) except that the shuffling of the discrete time series is specified here by the newOrderings parameter.

        Parameters:
        newOrderings - the specific new orderings to use. First index is for the new ordering number; second index is, for that particular reordering, which time point of the original series to grab at that point.
        Returns:
        the proportion of MI scores from the distribution which have higher or equal MIs to ours.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        computeSignificance(int)

        void setDebug(boolean debug)
